Recommended By Curators
"A game that redefined the stealth genre. With an amazing set of features, a gripping world and some of the purest stealth gameplay ever seen. "

About This Game

Stalk your prey on the quest for stolen goods with your blackjack, sword, and an assortment of unique arrows. Steal for money and uncover the hidden agendas of your allies and enemies as you play through an unravelling story of deception and revenge. Survive in a world where shadows are your only ally, trust is not an option, and confrontation results in death!

Key Features:

  • Pioneering stealth based gameplay brings a new dimension to first person action.
  • Thief™ Gold includes Thief™ The Dark Project (12 huge missions with multiple environments) and the Gold update (3 new campaign missions which deepen the plot and add five new types of enemies)
  • Advanced enemies can see, hear, speak, and sound alarms.
  • Your arsenal includes: blackjack, sword, fire arrows, water arrows, rope arrows and more
READ MORE

System Requirements

    • OS: Windows XP or Windows Vista
    • Processor: 1.8 GHz Processor
    • Memory: 512MB RAM (1 GB recommended)
    • Hard Disk Space: 2GB HDD
    • Video Card: 3D graphics card compatible with DirectX 7 (compatible with DirectX 9 recommended)
    • DirectX®: 7
READ MORE

Posted: August 7
1998.

That date should hopefully mean something to you. 1998 was the harbringer of classic video games. 1998 counted among its releases Unreal, Fallout 2, Ocarina of Time, Half Life, Grim Fandango, and more.

But among those releases is Thief: The Dark Project, otherwise known as Thief Gold on steam.

What was the point of bringing up the date? Because it doesn't matter how old it is. If you haven't layed Thief yet, it's still new to you. It's the grandfather of stealth and is ready to welcome you into its arms.

Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny
19 of 22 people (86%) found this review helpful
jacob_meyer.png
70 products in account
3 reviews
Recommended
92.3 hrs on record
Posted: August 14
Thief Gold is an updated re-release of the 1998 title, Thief: The Dark Project. Among other things, this could be considered the definitive beginning of the series.

Thief is a game about exactly what it says in the title, a First-Person Stealth game (a First-Person Sneaker, if you will) in which you try to steal things without getting caught. Now before I go any further, I'm going to disclaim that The Dark Project is the first PC game I ever completed and I'll try to make this an objective, nostalgia-free review.

Thief places you in the shoes of Garrett, a cynical anti-hero with a talent for shady errands. Garrett is a contemptful acolyte of a secret society of heroes known as the Keepers. The Keepers themselves work underneath the public gaze, pulling strings to stop the powerful factions of the city from rending their fragile homes apart. The city is in a perpetual conflict between the Order of the Hammer and the Pagan worshippers. The Hammerites run a religious march of progress, fanatically driven to forge and design under their god, the Builder, and to smite all who disrupt their faith. The Pagans have very different ideals; they live among nature, practicing magic and taming beasts to defend themselves from forces of the Hammers. Between these forces the enigmatic world of 'The City' is a proving ground for questionable motives and divided loyalties.

If you think that sounds a little bit much to contend with, you're in good company. Garrett makes a point to abandon his alien role with the Keepers in order to pursue his own interests, which are primarily expensive pieces that never rightfully belonged to him. The earliest missions in Thief see you casing manors in order to steal priceless valuables for the sake of paying rent. Unfortunately, Garrett's poor choice of associates threatens to drag him back into the fray. The slow but sure building suspicion and rising action of 'Thief' is a prime example of the expositional plots Looking Glass would become known for.

Playing Thief, you will spend a lot of time stealing things, and the sprawling, quiet episodes of kleptomania is what this game does best. The typical mission requires you to scout a place you're not welcome in, complete a contract for a valuable item and line your pockets with everything worth having. And with Garrett's set of talents, this is typically done by using discretion to avoid being detected.

True to form in a stealth game, you avoid enemies and use your tools to help conceal your presence. It's easily the most polished and enjoyable aspect of the game. Because of the first-person perspective, it can be very challenging considering you draw line of sight with enemies at roughly the same time they do with you, unless you manage to get behind them or conceal yourself. However, this game uses Looking Glass' style of world-building to great effect and there are always opportunities to clear areas using your skills. For an early 3D first-person game, the Dark Engine supports superb lighting and sound, both of which are your greatest allies. When you find a large, dark shadow, you can hide in it while remaining invisible to enemies until they get within a few feet of you. In addition to avoiding visual detection, you also have to avoid being heard, which is where the game's robust sound comes in. Audio feedback allows players to understand roughly how much noise they make as well as deduce the location of enemies from a distance. Sounds can also be made by throwing objects or using noisemaker arrows to create a distraction. It's very genuine, and for the most part, it works very well.

Which makes this as good a time as any to discuss your tools. Being a thief, Garrett equips himself with stealth-centralized tools like his blackjack, flashbombs and bow. The blackjack can knock an enemy unconscious, but only if you attack them when you're undetected. The flashbombs are a thief's favorite emergency problem-solver but I think the bow should be elaborated on: in Thief the bow is much more of a tool than a weapon and this is owed to the variety of trick arrows you can use with it. Aside from the basic arrowheads, you can equip water arrows, noisemaker arrows and rope arrows when the situation demands it. For example, whenever you need to make a new hiding place you can extinguish torches with your water arrows. When you spot a plate metal floor that's too noisy to walk on, simply tag it with an earth arrow to cover it in soft, quiet moss. And if you get detected, you can use the rare gas arrow to quietly knockout your opponent before they sound alarms. While you will be spending most of your heist intake on munitions, I rarely ran out of utility arrows and I never truly got tired of using the bow to solve problems.

In Thief the mission progression is very basic, between missions you get a cutscene that depicts the aftermath of the last job, followed immediately by the next mission briefing, in which you get to set the difficulty and buy gear for the next heist. Difficulty comes in three settings, in which higher levels require you to accomplish additional objectives, steal a goal amount of loose valuables or even place restrictions on how you deal with enemies. When you're playing on the highest difficulty (which I recommend doing) you often get commissions for additional items and generally need 60-85% of the total loot to pass the job, and the job will even be failed if you kill ANY humans. The threat and challenge are very genuine and the difficulty has a great effect on how you complete a job. Also, the loot system is just a little unorthodox so let me elaborate on that. Income from the previous mission MUST be spent during briefing or else it is lost. You lose all unused gear when you finish a mission and all unspent money when you start a mission; there's no in-game justification for this, it's just done to encourage you to actively use your assets and work in the present, and for the most part it's good fun.

The missions themeselves can be very hit or miss in my opinion, and this seems to polarize most players. The scale of the missions is always pretty massive, which can make for some absurdly rich, winding maps that can provide long, bountiful jobs. Unfortunately you're not going to spend all of your time enjoying this. Many of the heists leave the urban regions and require you to adventure through vast tombs and subterranean societies. These setpieces are pretty pleasing asthetically, but they're not all there in practice. Getting lost is a major problem with the scope of these maps and I often found that the light-mapping was inconsistent in these areas. Remember, in this game lighting can determine whether enemies can see you or not, so this often amounts to cheap alerts. And that's to say nothing of the sub-par platforming that rears its ugly head. This style of level design is all over the game, but I'd have to say some serious offenders would be the Thieve's Guild, the Bonehoard and the Haunted Cathedral. You'd be forgiven for thinking that this would ruin the game, but if you're patient, it's reconciliable. There are still good jobs to do that can offer 2-3 hours of espionage each, and that's not even including the dozens of FREE fan missions you can install, my favorite of which is 'Between These Dark Walls'. I'd estimate that between the 150+ fan missions and 15 mission story, you're probably looking at 35+ hours of entertainment, even when you take into account that 90% of fan missions are complete garbage.

Finally, if you're considering getting this just know that it has a few grievances all but absent from modern games. You have to forgive the (complete lack of) any inventory/document system, the lack of player-assistance and that you may need to patch it to run it properly.

39.7 hrs on record
Posted: May 15
Thief: The Dark Project is my favorite game in the stealth genre

from the geniuses behind System Shock comes Thief:The Dark Project,the first game where lighting was used as a new gameplay element,different from most first person games you need to use the darkness to your advantage,hiding yourself in the shadows was a new concept back then,becoming the standard for the next games in the stealth genre

you play as Garrett a master thief who doesn't care if the world is burning,as long it doesn't get in his way of stealing. Garrett is a memorable character,his lines are really well written and just like most characters in the 90's and 80's,he's got some one-liners.

the gameplay holds up to this date,in fact its unique because there aren't many first-person games,where you need to stay hidden in the shadows,you actually feel like a Thief

i highly recommend this game to any stealth fan,if you loved Dishonored you will love this game

Rektz
110 products in account
1 review
Recommended
64.0 hrs on record
Posted: August 14
This is one of the best and most memorable games I have ever, and will ever play. Let's start.

Gold is The Dark Project from all those years ago, but with a few extra maps. If you played TDP like I did back in the day but you haven't played Gold, I suggest you go ahead. There's not much to say about this game honestly. Everyone knows this game, and if you don't, come out from under that rock your hiding under and join us. Go watch some HD gameplay of this beast and you will see why this game is held in such high reguard. To give you some perspective, the creative mind behind the art and graphical style of Gold is also the man who did the same for BioShock™, AND BioShock: Infinite™.

This is one of my favourite games of all time. The story is mind-blowingly awesome, and the gameplay is REALLY good for it's age. It's extremely playable to this day, similar to Half-Life™. One noteworthy thing to add, this game has unofficial bug-fixes as well as a HD mod. So do the rest apparently. I'm installing the HD mod for TMA now.

Please play this game. It's addictive and it's one of those games that is easily playable, and there's always something new to try out.
